an3.101:1.1: “Gold has coarse corruptions: sand, soil, and gravel.
an3.101:1.2: A panner or their apprentice pours it into a pan, where they wash, rinse, and clean it.
an3.101:1.3: When that’s been eliminated, there are medium corruptions in the gold: fine grit and coarse sand.
an3.101:1.5: When that’s been eliminated, there are fine corruptions in the gold: fine sand and black grime.
an3.101:1.7: When that’s been eliminated, only gold dust is left.
an3.101:1.8: A goldsmith or their apprentice places the gold in a crucible where they blow, melt, and smelt it.
an3.101:1.9: Still the gold is not settled and the dross is not totally gone. It’s not pliable, workable, or radiant, but is brittle and not completely ready for working.
an3.101:1.10: But the goldsmith keeps on blowing, melting, and smelting it.
an3.101:1.11: The gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and ready to be worked.
an3.101:1.12: Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.
an3.101:2.1: In the same way, a mendicant who is committed to the higher mind has coarse corruptions: bad bodily, verbal, and mental conduct. A sincere, capable mendicant gives these up, gets rid of, eliminates, and obliterates them.
an3.101:2.2: When they’ve been given up and eliminated, there are middling corruptions: sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts. A sincere, capable mendicant gives these up, gets rid of, eliminates, and obliterates them.
an3.101:2.3: When they’ve been given up and eliminated, there are fine corruptions: thoughts of family, country, and being looked up to. A sincere, capable mendicant gives these up, gets rid of, eliminates, and obliterates them.
an3.101:2.4: When they’ve been given up and eliminated, only thoughts about the teaching are left.
an3.101:2.5: That immersion is not peaceful or sublime or tranquil or unified, but is held in place by forceful suppression.
an3.101:2.6: But there comes a time when that mind is stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
an3.101:2.7: That immersion is peaceful and sublime and tranquil and unified, not held in place by forceful suppression.
an3.101:2.8: They become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
an3.101:3.1: If they wish: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with my hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling my body as far as the Brahmā realm.’
an3.101:3.2: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an3.101:4.1: If they wish: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.’
an3.101:4.2: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an3.101:5.1: If they wish: ‘May I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with my mind. May I understand mind with greed as “mind with greed”, and mind without greed as “mind without greed”; mind with hate as “mind with hate”, and mind without hate as “mind without hate”; mind with delusion as “mind with delusion”, and mind without delusion as “mind without delusion”; constricted mind as “constricted mind”, and scattered mind as “scattered mind”; expansive mind as “expansive mind”, and unexpansive mind as “unexpansive mind”; mind that is not supreme as “mind that is not supreme”, and mind that is supreme as “mind that is supreme”; mind immersed in samādhi as “mind immersed in samādhi”, and mind not immersed in samādhi as “mind not immersed in samādhi”; freed mind as “freed mind”, and unfreed mind as “unfreed mind”.’
an3.101:5.2: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an3.101:6.1: If they wish: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I recollect my many past lives, with features and details.’
an3.101:6.2: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an3.101:7.1: If they wish: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they acted out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they acted out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.” And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. And may I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.’
an3.101:7.2: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an3.101:8.1: If they wish: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
an3.101:8.2: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.”
